sub: How to cook without a kitchen
com:
So I'm renting an apartment (it's literally just a room with a sink and acloset) in chinatown and we don't have a kitchen. I already have a multi function rice cooker which can make oatmeal (breakfast) and rice (dinner) but now I want to cook chicken for my lunch as well.
I am wondering what the best appliance to cook with is.
I do NOT care about (((flavor))) or (((cost))) but what I DO care about is that it's small and easy to clean
Imagine you have to do dishes in your bathroom sink, that's the size of my sink.
Should I get a small 2 quart air fryer and just cook one chicken thigh at a time? Or is a traditional toaster oven a better idea?
Should I just boil a whole chicken in a crock pot? Or will that take up too much space and be impossible to clean.
Again, I DO NOT CARE about the quality of the chicken I literally just want to heat the internal temperature of the chicken to 165F and then clean up in a bathroom size sink.
Any advice much appreciated,
Thanks :D

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
instant pot
you can also clean it in your bathtub if ur sink is too small

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
Did you make the OP pic? It's neat
Speaking from experience, an air fryer is really effective and simple to clean. Dunno about your store situation where you are, but I saw a ninja air fryer at walmart for $69.99
I don't have an electric grill, but my aunt uses one whenever she does pork chops. They can double as griddles or panini makers and can hold more food than an air fryer. Pic related shows size. Only downside is that they usually max out at 300 Fahrenheit.
My final recommendation is air fryer. Alternately, you could go the minimalist route and just buy a clothing iron to do your meats. You can get one for like $20 lol.

>>18677185
Macallan is decent but these days grossly overpriced. It was my first introduction to whisky 20 years ago, but over the years chinks have been buying it up en masse because all they give a shit about is the label, branding and “perceived image” of the goods, and not what’s in the actual fucking bottle. And thus we’re now in a situation where the prices are well and truly out of whack. It’s decent stuff but nowhere near the price they’re asking for these days. Sure, for some people it’s what they like, since taste is after all a personal thing. But even for me — as someone who grew up around Macallen (I was previously in F&B (fine dining specifically)) — I just find it’s absolutely not worth it. I’d rather go for variety and there’s many solid options out there for much better prices. The key to whisky is: don’t let anyone tell you what’s good. Decide for yourself what you like. There’s nothing wrong in being in love with a cheap young bottle if that’s what you like. Don’t force yourself to like something just because someone tells you it’s what you’re supposed to like because of xyz reason.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
New local drop of a limited whiskey. Good nose with some graham cracker and some kind of like sour apple or pear peel and a little scotchy note like being outdoors innawoods. Also booze, this shit is strong. Tastes like treacle or golden molasses with an oak tree scraping your throat as you swallow. Mild finish after that with more lingering treacle. Much like everything Virginia made, it tastes like the background radiation of this beautiful shithole.

Corn, wheat and barley on the bill. I'm definitely getting some single pot Irish shenanigans from the barley but this is a distinctly American whisk(e)y that isn't bourbon. Very smooth for the proof, even the barrel wall in the swaller is pleasant. It does feel like a tree is going to grow out my throat but Eagle Rare does that too.

Would rec.

You bring up a good point. I drank the fuck out of the yamazaki when it was 50 bucks and dabbled as it climbed to 90 but it's 150 where I live now and not worth that at all. It blows most scotch under 80-100 out the fucking water but I really like that granny's apple pie a la mode in a bottle thing it does. If you can't pick up on the subtleties or the place it takes you doesn't work for you, it's not good for you.

Macallan is a safe bet if you're like in a bar or travelling and find a good deal on it. Also the marketing makes anything taste better up until you have something you actually like. I wouldn't push >>18677596 on anyone because I have had bad, but highly rated, recs that didn't do it for me at all. Still reccing it because good whisky you don't like is better than bad whisky. You need that frame of reference and ripping the band-aid off to find out a ~30 buck throw in the sheets blows that first 60 dollar sip out the fucking water for you personally is a powerful referent.

If you learn {X TECHNICAL SKILL} in mostly easy, basic ways, just use it whenever. If you learn how to do {X} in more advanced ways, then using it depends on more subtle things.

last_replies.name: Anonymous

Not true, and this has been studied quite a bit. It takes a long-ass time for a significant amount of alcohol to boil/evaporate off, even at high heats. If you're cooking for someone like a Muslim or Mormon guest for example, you either have to only use low-alcohol cooking wines, or be using them in long-cooking processes (30+ minutes for a decent amount, 3 hours to get it all).
https://www.foodnetwork.com/how-to/packages/food-network-essentials/cooking-wine-does-alcohol-burn-off

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
You don't "knead" cookie dough. Kneading is for developing gluten for more chew and texture, like you'd do for bread. For cookies, first mix the fat and sugar until well combined. Then add the remaining wet ingredients (eggs, vanilla, etc). When that's homogeneous, mix in the dry ingredients until it's combined.

To answer your question: yes, you can use a hand mixer, it'll just take longer than in a stand mixer. If you WERE using a stand mixer to make cookies you would use the paddle attachment, not the dough hook.

I'm suspicious of your recipe. Post it so I can have a look at it.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
At Vietnamese deli/convenience/snacks/whatever stores, they have huge medicine jars full of various types of jerky. The red one with visible bits of chilli on it is really good. I think it's pork. I know the oddly vaguely purple one, which is quite sweet but also very good, is beef, and the red one has a different texture, so pretty sure it's pork. They even have fish ones, though I have no idea wtf sort of fish it is, though I think it's threadfin or bream.
Anyway, if you have such a store near you, I strongly rec that you go there and have a look at the counter or the wall behind the till. That's where the jars have been in literally all such Vietnamese deli/whatevers I've been to. The jerky can be a tad costly, tho, so I only get it very occasionally. The pork one makes for fantastic fried rice. some onion, a bit of lard, the rice, a scrambled egg, the chopped jerky, some beansprouts and a finishing touch of chopped garlic chives and you've got some good eatin', frens.
The purple jerky is really good with yanang soup. Idk wtf yanang is called in English, but it's called san choi in Cantonese. You rub the leaves in water (or just blend it) and they kind of melt into a green extract that's weirdly slime-y, but you make the soup with lots of bamboo shoot and some pork, chicken or fish stock (freshwater only, idky) and eat that shit with chopped purple jerky that you singe over open flame and either broken rice or sticky rice.
I wish SEA monkey home cooking was better known cuz while the resto stuff is good, the home stuff is just a whole 'nother animal.
